trial_identification.studytitle: Active Wear for Everyone (AWE): The effect of wearing the school sports uniform on childrens physical activity
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial to measure the effect of school sports uniform attire on physical activity of primary school children

interventions.interventions: Sixty NSW primary schools will be randomised to either a one day intervention or control. Students in grades 2 and 3 attending the intervention schools will wear their sports uniform for one day (when they would normally wear a traditional uniform) and which is not their scheduled sports day. The one day that the students wear their sports uniform will be randomly allocated. Teachers will be asked to note which students forget to wear uniform on the particular day. Nothing else will be required of schools or students. Students in control schools will continue with normal uniform practices for the school week.
interventions.comparator: Usual practice (no change to uniform requirements)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Girls physical activity- mean minutes of MVPA per day will be measured objectively using wrist-worn accelerometers, by students in grade 2-3 at all schools for 5 consecutive school days. Data will be analysed for whole school day as well as segmented.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and for the one day during intervention exposure

primaryOutcome.outcome: Girls physical activity- mean physical activity counts per minute will be measured objectively using wrist-worn accelerometers, by students in grade 2-3 at all schools for 5 consecutive school days. Data will be analysed for whole school day as well as segmented..
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and for the one day during intervention exposure

secondaryOutcome.outcome: All students physical activity- mean physical activity counts per minute will be measured objectively using wrist-worn accelerometers, by students in grade 2-3 at all schools for 5 consecutive school days. Data will be analysed for whole school day as well as segmented.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and for the one day during intervention exposure

secondaryOutcome.outcome: All students physical activity-mean minutes of MVPA per day will be measured objectively using wrist-worn accelerometers, by students in grade 2-3 at all schools for 5 consecutive school days. Data will be analysed for whole school day as well as segmented.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and for the one day during intervention exposure

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Catholic primary schools within the Hunter New England Local Health District and Mid North Coast Local Health District of NSW will be invited to participate. All grade 2 and 3 students at eligible schools will be invited to participate.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Schools will be ineligible if they; cater exclusively for children requiring specialist care; are already involved in a physical activity trial; and/or currently only have a sports uniform that children wear each day. All students in grades 2 and 3 are eligible to participate in the trial

trial_design.concealment: Schools will be randomised in a 1:1 ratio to either an intervention or control group via a central randomisation process by computer Block randomisation will be employed to ensure group allocation is approximately equal. Data collectors will be blind to group allocation. Due to the nature of the intervention school staff will be aware of their group allocation.
trial_design.sequence: An independent statistician will use a computerised random number function to randomise schools in a 1:1 ratio

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of this randomised control trial is to evaluate whether students, in particular girls, are more active during the school day if they are wearing their sports uniform as opposed to their normal formal uniform. Sixty primary schools in the Hunter Region and Mid North Coast will be randomly allocated to an intervention or control group.
